slides.text: The study got a bit of attention on dozens of outlets. The headline: A person’s ability to be random peaks at 25 years old and declines after 60.
We initially set out to use the findings to make an age guessing game, but after analyzing the data we lost confidence it would yield good results.

We don’t think the randomness study’s findings are reproducible because of the researchers’ decision to include “bad” responses. To us, a bad response means the participant either misunderstood the instructions, or intentionally sabotaged the experiment. That decision was the difference between “ah this is interesting” and “welp, nothing here” (or “null results” in statistics lingo).
Here are the instructions from the original study:
Here is an example of a <mark class=good>good</mark> and <mark class=bad>bad</mark> dice roll sequence based on their classifying algorithm.

Do you think the bad response looks “real” and satisfies the instructions? We don’t. The researchers behind the study did (and confirmed with us via email). And this disagreement has a big statistical impact.
Here is the key chart from the study that shows the developmental curve of complexity for the coin toss experiment.

steps.text: Think of the complexity score as a proxy for randomness; higher up means more random, lower down means less random. Here are a <mark class=good>few examples</mark> (H for heads, T for tails).
Here is your score. Your answer got a higher random score than of people in the study.
When we add a <mark class=good>trend line,</mark> we can see the age drop-off finding take shape.
At the bottom are the <mark class=bad>bad responses</mark>. We even took a conservative approach to defining bad; just the ones that were entirely heads or tails.
When we exclude the bad responses, the trend disappears.

slides.text: Although that example was just for the coin toss, the trend line has the same shape when you look at the aggregate results.

The study was peer-reviewed, not reproduced. This is normal since it takes significantly more time and effort to reproduce versus review. This means it is highly likely that the reviewers didn’t run their own data analysis either, which makes it far easier to miss a small but important decision like the one we found.
The experiment at the start of this story was our attempt to do our own replication. Here are the live results of that process.
TK discuss how results are the same or different.

The moral of the story: just because you read about a study from a New York Times headline, it doesn’t mean others have been able to reproduce the same results. Maybe you knew that, but a friendly reminder nonetheless. Oh, and if you are over 60, go ahead with the confidence that you can still be as random as you were in your 20s.
